highlights.para: This chapter describes how to use the Nautilus file manager.

sect1.title: Introduction to Nautilus File Manager
sect1.para: The Nautilus file manager provides an integrated access point to your files, applications, and the World Wide Web. Nautilus enables you to do the following:

listitem.para: Display your files and folders.
Manage your files and folders.
Customize your files and folders.
Browse websites.

sect1.para: Nautilus also manages the desktop where your panels, menus, and windows are displayed.
Nautilus windows enable you to display and manage your files and folders. You can open a Nautilus window in any of the following ways:

listitem.para: Double-click on the Home object on the desktop background.

Open the Global Menu, then choose
Programs Applications Nautilus .
Right-click on the desktop background to open the Desktop Background menu. Choose New Window.

sect1.para: The Nautilus window displays the contents of your home location in the view pane.

sect1.para: You can also use Nautilus to browse the Web. shows a Nautilus window that displays the contents of a website.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of a website in a Nautilus window

sect1.para: You can also open a popup menu from Nautilus windows. To open this popup menu right-click in a Nautilus window. The items in this menu depend on where you right-click. For example, when you right-click on a file or folder, you can choose items related to the file or folder. When you right-click on the background of a view pane, you can choose items related to the display of items in the view pane.

sect2.title: View Pane
sect2.para: The view pane can display the contents of the following:

listitem.para: Particular types of files
Folders
Websites

sect2.para: Nautilus enables you to display particular types of file in the view pane. For example, you can display HTML files in the view pane. The following figure shows a plain text document displayed in the view pane.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of a Nautilus view pane

sect2.para: Displaying a file in the view pane provides the following benefits:

listitem.para: Uses less system resources than when you launch an application.
Takes less time than when you launch an application.

sect2.para: However, you can not edit a file in the view pane.
Click on the Refresh button to refresh the contents of the view pane.

Nautilus provides several ways to display the contents of your files. Nautilus includes viewers that enable you to display particular types of file in the view pane. For example you can use a web page viewer to display HTML files in the view pane.
Nautilus includes views that enable you to display the contents of your folders in different ways. For example, you can display the contents of a folder in the following type of view:

listitem.para: Icon view: Displays the items in the folder as icons.
List view: Displays the items in the folder as a list.

sect2.para: Use the View as drop-down list box to choose how to display a file or folder. For more information on views, see .

sect2.title: Navigation Pane

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of a Nautilus navigation pane

sect2.para: The navigation pane can contain the following elements:

listitem.para: An icon that represents the current file or current folder. The navigation pane also contains information about the current file or current folder.
Tabbed panes that enable you to navigate through your files and the online help system.
If a file is displayed in the view pane, buttons appear in the navigation pane. The buttons enable you to perform actions on a file, other than the default action.

sect2.title: Tabbed Panes
sect2.para:
The navigation pane contains the following tabbed panes:
Help: Enables you to navigate through the information resources in the online help system.
History: Contains a history list of files, folders, and URLs that you have recently visited.
Notes: Enables you to add notes to your folders.
Tree: Displays a hierarchical representation of your file system. You can use the Tree tabbed pane to navigate through your files.
describes how to work with tabbed panes.

sect2.title: Icons and Emblems
sect2.para: In icon view, Nautilus displays your files and folders as icons. You can add emblems to your file icons and folder icons. An emblem is a small icon that you can add to an item to visually mark the item. For example, to mark a file as important, you can add an Important emblem to the file icon to create the following visual effect:

sect1.title: Navigating Your Computer and the Internet
sect1.para: Each Nautilus window displays the contents of a single file, folder, or URL. This section describes the following:

listitem.para: How to display items in Nautilus windows.
How to open files from Nautilus windows.
How to navigate the files and folders in your file system.
How to navigate the Internet.

sect2.title: To Display Your Home Location

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of Nautilus home location icon

sect2.para: To display your home location, perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: Double-click on the Home object on the desktop background.

On a Nautilus window, choose
Go Home .
On a Nautilus window, click on the Home toolbar button.

sect2.para: The Nautilus window displays the contents of your home location. To refresh the display, click on the Refresh button.
For information on how to set your home location, see .

sect2.title: To Display a Folder
sect2.para: You can display the contents of a folder in any of the following ways:

listitem.para: Double-click on the folder in the view pane.

In the Location field, type the path of the folder that you want to display, then press Return. The Location field includes an autocomplete feature. That is, as you type a path, Nautilus reads your file system. When you type enough characters to uniquely identify a directory, Nautilus completes the name of the directory in the Location field.
Use the Tree tabbed pane. For more information, see .
Use the Back toolbar button and the Forward toolbar button to browse through your navigation history.

sect2.para:
To change to the folder that is one level above the current folder, choose
Go Up a Level . Alternatively, click on the Up toolbar button.
To refresh the display, click on the Refresh button.

sect2.title: Using the Tree Tabbed Pane
sect2.para: The Tree tabbed pane displays a hierarchical representation of your file system. The Tree tabbed pane provides a convenient way to navigate your file system. The following figure shows the Tree tabbed pane.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of Tree tabbed pane

sect2.para: In the Tree tabbed pane, folders are represented as follows:

entry.para: Folder State
Graphic Representation
Closed folder
Right arrow
Open folder
Down arrow

sect2.para: You can set your preferences so that the Tree tabbed pane does not display files. For more information, see .
If you set your Nautilus user level to Beginner, the Tree tabbed pane is not displayed in your navigation pane. For more information, see .

sect2.title: Opening Files
sect2.para: When you open a file, Nautilus performs the default action for that file type. The default action can be one of the following:

listitem.para: Launch an application that opens the file.
Use a viewer to display the file in the view pane.

sect2.para: Nautilus checks the contents of a file to determine the type of a file. If the first lines do not determine the type of the file, then Nautilus checks the file extension.

sect3.title: To Execute the Default Action
sect3.para: To execute the default action for a file, double-click on the file. For example, if the default action for plain text documents is to display the file in a text viewer, Nautilus displays the file in a text viewer.
You can set your Nautilus preferences so that you click once on a file to execute the default action. For more information, see .

sect3.title: To Execute Non-Default Actions Using the Open With Submenu
sect3.para: To execute actions other than the default action for a file, perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
In the view pane, select the file that you want to perform an action on. Choose
File Open With . The Open With submenu opens. The items in this submenu correspond to the contents of the following parts of the File Types and Programs capplet:
Edit Applications List dialog
Edit Components List dialog
Choose an action from the Open With submenu.

sect3.title: To Execute Other Actions When Displaying a File
sect3.para: When you display a file in the view pane, the navigation pane might contain buttons. shows the navigation pane when a text file is displayed in the view pane.

figure.title: Navigation Pane When a File is Displayed in the View Pane

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of the navigation pane

sect3.para: The buttons represent any actions that are defined in the Edit Applications List dialog on the File Types and Programs capplet. Click on a button to execute an action. For example, if an action defined for plain text documents is to open the file in gedit. If this action is defined, an Open with gedit button is displayed in the navigation pane. To open the file in the gedit application, click on the Open with gedit button.

note.para:
A button that represents the action does not appear in the navigation pane if the actions are excluded in either of the following dialogs:
Open with Other
View as Other

sect2.title: To Navigate the World Wide Web
sect2.para: You can use Nautilus as a browser to display websites. To display a website, type the URL for the site in the field on the location bar, then press Return. The contents of the site are displayed in the view pane. To reload the current page, click on the Refresh button.

When you display a website in the view pane, the navigation pane might contain buttons. The buttons represent any actions that you can perform on the web page that is displayed in the view pane. To execute an action on the web page, click on the button that represents the action.
For example, when you display a HTML document in the view pane, an Open with Netscape button is displayed in the navigation pane. To open the file in Netscape, click on the Open with Netscape button.
You can also use Nautilus to access FTP sites.

sect2.title: To Search the World Wide Web
sect2.para: To access a search engine website click on the Web Search toolbar button. The search engine website is displayed in the view pane.
You can set the web search service that Nautilus uses. For more information, see .

sect2.title: Using Your Navigation History
sect2.para: Nautilus maintains a history list of files, folders, and URLs. You can use the history list to navigate to files, folders, and URLs that you have recently visited. The following sections describe how to navigate your history list.

To clear your history list choose
Go Forget History .

sect3.title: To Navigate Your History List Using the Go Menu
sect3.para: To display a list of previously-viewed items, choose the Go menu. Your history list is displayed in the lower part of the Go menu. To go to an item in your history list, choose the item from the Go menu.

sect3.title: To Navigate Your History List Using the Toolbar
sect3.para: To use the toolbar to navigate your history list, perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: To go to the previous file, folder, or URL in your history list, click on the Back toolbar button.
To go to the next file, folder, or URL in your history list, click on the Forward toolbar button.
To display a list of previously-viewed items, right-click on the Back toolbar button. To go to an item from this list, click on the item.

sect3.title: To Navigate Your History List Using the History Tabbed Pane
sect3.para: To display the History tabbed pane, click on the History tab in the navigation pane. The History tabbed pane displays a list of your previously-viewed items, as shown in the following figure:

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of History tabbed pane

sect3.para: To display an item from your history list in the view pane, click on the item in your History tabbed pane.

sect2.title: To Bookmark Your Favorite Locations
sect2.para: To access an item in your bookmarks, choose the item from the Bookmarks menu. You can add your favorite locations to your Bookmarks menu. You can add bookmarks to locations on the Internet, or to files and folders in your file system.
By default, Nautilus contains certain bookmarks. You can set your Nautilus preferences so that the default bookmarks are excluded from the Bookmarks menu. For more information, see .

sect3.title: To Add a Bookmark
sect3.para:
To add a bookmark, display the item that you want to bookmark in the view pane. Choose
Bookmarks Add Bookmark .

sect3.title: To Edit a Bookmark
sect3.para: To edit your bookmarks perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
Choose
Bookmarks Edit Bookmarks . A Bookmarks dialog is displayed.
To edit a bookmark, select the bookmark on the left side of the Bookmarks dialog. Edit the details for the bookmark on the right side of the Bookmarks dialog as follows:

entry.para: Dialog Element
Description
Use this text box to specify the name that identifies the bookmark in the Bookmarks menu.
Use this field to specify the location of the bookmark.

listitem.para: To remove a bookmark, select the bookmark on the left side of the dialog. Click Remove.

sect1.title: Managing Your Files and Folders
sect1.para: This section describes how to work with your files and folders.

sect2.title: Drag-and-Drop in Nautilus
sect2.para: You can use drag-and-drop to perform several tasks in Nautilus. When you drag-and-drop, the mouse pointer provides feedback about the task that you perform. describes the tasks that you can perform with drag-and-drop. The table also shows the mouse pointers that appear when you drag-and-drop.

entry.para: Task
Action
Mouse Pointer
Move an item
Drag the item to the new location.

entry.para: Copy an item
Press and hold Ctrl, then drag the item to the new location.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of copy pointer

entry.para: Link to an item
Press and hold Shift, then drag the item to the location where you want the link to reside.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of link pointer

Press and hold Alt , then drag the item to the location where you want the item to reside. Release the mouse button. A popup menu appears. Choose one of the following items from the popup menu:

Copies the item to the location.
Creates a symbolic link to the item at the location.

sect2.title: To Select Files and Folders
sect2.para: You can select files and folders in several ways in Nautilus. describes how to select items in Nautilus windows and on the Nautilus desktop background.

entry.para: Task
Action
Select an item
Click on the item.
Select a group of contiguous items
Press and hold Shift. Click on the first item in the group, then click on the last item in the group.
Alternatively, drag around the files that you want to select.
Select multiple items
Press and hold Ctrl. Click on the items that you want to select.
Alternatively, press and hold Ctrl, then drag around the files that you want to select.
Select all items in a folder

Choose
Edit Select All Files .

sect2.para: To perform the default action on an item, double-click on the item. You can set your Nautilus preferences so that you work with Nautilus as follows:

listitem.para: Click once on a file to execute the default action.
Point to an item to select the item.

sect2.para: For more information, see .

sect2.title: To Move a File or Folder
sect2.para: To move a file or folder perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
Open a Nautilus window. Choose
File New Window to open a second Nautilus window.
In one window, select the folder from which you want to move the file or folder. In the other window, select the folder to which you want to move the file or folder.
Drag the file or folder that you want to move to the new location in the other window.

sect2.para: To move the file or folder to a folder that is one level below the current location, do not open a new window. Instead, drag the file or folder to the new location in the same window.

You can also use the Tree tabbed pane to move a file or folder. You can drag a file or folder from the view pane to a location on the Tree tabbed pane. Alternatively, you can drag a file or folder within the Tree tabbed pane to another location in the Tree tabbed pane.

sect2.title: To Copy a File or Folder
sect2.para: To copy a file or folder perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
Open a Nautilus window. Choose
File New Window to open a second Nautilus window.
In one window, select the folder from which you want to copy the file or folder. In the other window, select the folder to which you want to copy the file or folder.
Press and hold Ctrl, then drag the file or folder to the new location in the other window.

sect2.para: To copy the file or folder to a folder that is one level below the current location, do not open a new window. Instead, press Ctrl and drag the file or folder to the new location in the same window.

sect2.title: To Duplicate a File or Folder
sect2.para: To create a copy of a file or folder in the current folder perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the file or folder that you want to duplicate in the view pane.

Choose
File Duplicate . Alternatively, right-click on the file or folder in the view pane, then choose Duplicate.
A copy of the file or folder appears in the current folder.

sect2.title: To Create a Folder
sect2.para: To create a folder perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the folder where you want to create the new folder.

Choose
File New Folder . Alternatively, right-click on the background of the view pane, then choose New Folder.
An untitled folder is added to the view pane. The name of the folder is selected.
Type a name for the folder, then press Return.

sect2.title: To Rename a File or Folder
sect2.para: To rename a file or folder perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the file or folder that you want to rename in the view pane.

Choose
File Rename . Alternatively, right-click on the file or folder in the view pane, then choose Rename.
The name of the file or folder is selected.
Type a new name for the file or folder, then press Return.

sect2.title: To Move a File or Folder to Trash
sect2.para: To move a file or folder to Trash perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the file or folder that you want to move to Trash in the view pane.

Choose
File Move to Trash . Alternatively, right-click on the file or folder in the view pane, then choose Move to Trash.

sect2.para: Alternatively, you can drag the file or folder from the view pane to the Trash icon on the desktop.

sect2.title: To Create a Symbolic Link to a File or Folder
sect2.para: A symbolic link is a special type of file that points to another file or folder. When you perform an action on a symbolic link, the action is performed on the file or folder to which the symbolic link points. However, when you delete a symbolic link, you delete the link file, not the file to which the symbolic link points.

To create a symbolic link to a file or folder, select the file or folder to which you want to create a link. Choose
File Create Link . A link to the file or folder is added to the current folder.
Alternatively, press and hold Shift. Drag the item to which you want to create a link to the location where you want to place the link.
By default, Nautilus adds an emblem to symbolic links.

sect2.title: To Change Permissions
sect2.para: To change the permissions on a file or folder perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the file or folder whose permissions you want to change.

Choose
File Show Properties . A properties dialog is displayed.
Click on the Permissions tab. In the Permissions tabbed section, use the drop-down list boxes and check boxes to change the permissions for the file or folder.
Use the Window menu to close the properties dialog.

sect2.title: Using Trash

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of Nautilus Trash icon

sect2.para: You can move the following items to Trash:

listitem.para: Files
Folders
Desktop background objects

sect2.para: When you move an item to Trash, the item is temporarily stored in your /.Trash directory. If you need to retrieve a file from Trash, you can display Trash and move the file out of Trash.
When you empty Trash, you delete the contents of Trash permanently.

sect3.title: To Display Trash
sect3.para: You can display the contents of Trash in the following ways:

listitem.para: From a Nautilus window

Choose
File Show Trash . The contents of Trash are displayed in the window.
From the desktop background
Double-click on the Trash object on the desktop background.

sect3.title: To Empty Trash
sect3.para: You can empty the contents of Trash in the following ways:

listitem.para: From a Nautilus window

Choose
File Empty Trash .
From the desktop background
Right-click on the Trash object, then choose Empty Trash.

sect2.title: Adding Notes to Folders
sect2.para: You can use the Notes tab to add a note to a folder. To add a note to a folder perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Display the folder in the view pane.

Click on the Notes tab to open the Notes tabbed pane. The Notes tabbed pane opens, as shown in the following figure:
Screenshot of Notes tabbed pane
Type the note in the Notes tabbed pane.

sect1.title: Modifying the Appearance of Files and Folders

indexterm.secondary: modifying appearance of files and folders

sect1.para: This section describes how to modify the appearance of your files and folders in Nautilus.

sect2.title: To Add an Emblem to a File or Folder
sect2.para: You can add an emblem to an item in either of the following ways:

listitem.para: Use the Properties dialog.
Use the Backgrounds and Emblems dialog.

sect2.para: To add an emblem to an item with the Properties dialog, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the item to which you want to add an emblem.
Right-click on the item, then choose Show Properties . The Properties dialog is displayed.
Click on the Emblems tab to display the Emblems tabbed section, as shown in the following figure:

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of Emblems tabbed section on Properties dialog

listitem.para: Select the emblem to add to the item.
Use the Window menu to close the properties dialog.

sect2.para: To add an emblem to an item with the Backgrounds and Emblems dialog, perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
Choose
Edit Backgrounds and Emblems . The Backgrounds and Emblems dialog is displayed.
To display a list of emblems that you can add, click on the Emblems button.
To add an emblem to an item, drag the emblem to the item.
Click Done to close the dialog.

sect2.title: To Modify the Icon for a File or Folder
sect2.para: To change the icon that represents an individual file or folder, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the file or folder whose icon you want to change.

Choose
File Show Properties . A properties dialog is displayed.
On the Basic tabbed section, click on the Select Custom Icon button. A Select an icon dialog is displayed.
Use the Select an icon dialog to choose the icon to represent the file or folder.
Use the Window menu to close the properties dialog.

sect2.para: To change the icon that represents a file type, use the File Types and Programs capplet.

To restore an icon from a custom icon to the default icon specified in the File Types and Programs capplet, right-click on the icon then choose Remove Custom Image. Alternatively, click on the Remove Custom Icon button on the Show Properties dialog.

sect2.title: To Modify the Icon Caption for Files and Folders
sect2.para: An icon caption displays the name of a file or folder. The icon caption also includes three additional items of information on the file or folder. The additional information is displayed after the file name. Normally only one item of information is visible, but when you zoom in on an icon, more of the information is displayed. You can modify what additional information is displayed in icon captions.
To modify what information is displayed in icon captions, perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
Choose
Edit Icon Captions . An Icon Captions dialog is displayed.

Select the items of information to be displayed in the icon caption from the three drop-down list boxes. Select the first item from the first drop-down list box, select the second item from the second drop-down list box, and so on. The following table describes the items of information that you can select:

entry.para: Information
Description
Choose this option to display the size of the item.
Choose this option to display the description of the MIME type of the item from the File Types and Programs capplet.
Choose this option to display the last modification date of the item.

Choose this option to display the last modification date of the inode of the item. An inode is a data structure that contains information about individual files in UNIX file systems. There is one inode for each file. An inode contains the node, type, owner, and location of a file.
Choose this option to display the date that the item was last accessed.
Choose this option to display the owner of the item.

Choose this option to display the MIME type of the item.
Choose this option to display no information for the item.

listitem.para: Use the Window menu to close the Icon Captions dialog.

sect2.title: To Change the Size of Items in a View
sect2.para: You can change the size of items in a view. You change the size if the view displays a file or a folder. You can change the size of items in a view in the following ways:

listitem.para:
To enlarge the size of items in a view, choose
View Zoom In .

To reduce the size of items in a view, choose
View Zoom Out .

To return items in a view to the normal size, choose
View Normal Size .

sect2.para: You can also use the zoom buttons on the location bar to change the size of items in a view. describes how to use the zoom buttons.

Description

Click on this button to reduce the size of items in a view.

entry.para: Normal Size button
Click on this button to return items in a view to normal size.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of Zoom In button

Click on this button to enlarge the size of items in a view.

sect2.para: Nautilus remembers the size of items in a particular folder. The next time that you display the folder, the items are displayed in the size you selected. In other words, when you change the size of items in a folder, you customize the folder to display the items at that size.

sect2.title: Using Views to Display Your Files and Folders
sect2.para: Nautilus provides several ways to display the contents of your files. Nautilus includes viewers that enable you to display particular types of file in the view pane. For example, you can use a web page viewer to display HTML files in the view pane. You can use a text viewer to view plain text files in the view pane.
You can also use Nautilus to open a file in an appropriate application. For more information see .
Nautilus includes views that enable you to display the contents of your folders in different ways. For example, you can display the contents of a folder in the following type of view:

listitem.para: Icon view
Displays the items in the folder as icons. shows a folder displayed in icon view.
List view
Displays the items in the folder as a list. shows a folder displayed in list view.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of Nautilus window in list view

sect2.para: Use the View as drop-down list box to choose how to display a file or folder. When you display a folder, you can specify how you want to arrange or sort items in the folder. You can modify the size of the items in the view pane. The following sections describe how to work with icon view, list view, and views of files.

sect3.title: To Choose a View in Which to Display a File or Folder
sect3.para: Choose the type of view in which to display the contents of a file or folder from the View as drop-down list box. The View as drop-down list box is located at the right side of the location bar.
Alternatively, to choose a view, choose View as Other from the View as drop-down list box. Select the view that you want to use from the View as Other dialog, then click on the Choose button.

You can display different folders in different views. Nautilus remembers the view that you choose for a particular folder. The next time that you display the folder, Nautilus displays the folder in that view. In other words, when you choose a view for a folder, you customize the folder to always display in that view.

sect3.title: To Sort Your Files in Icon View
sect3.para:
When you display the contents of a folder in icon view, you can specify how to sort the items in the folder. To specify how to sort items in icon view, choose
View Lay Out Items . The Lay Out Items submenu contains the following sections:

listitem.para: The top section contains an option that enables you to sort your files manually.
The middle section contains options that enable you to sort your files automatically.
The bottom section contains options that enable you to modify how your files are sorted.

sect3.para: Choose the appropriate options from the submenu, as described in the following table:

entry.para: Option
Description
Select this option to arrange the items manually. To arrange the items manually, drag the items to the location you require within the view pane.
Select this option to sort the items alphabetically by name. The order of the items is not case sensitive. If you have selected to display hidden files, the hidden files are shown last.

Select this option to sort the items by size, with the largest item first. When you sort items by size, the folders are sorted by the number of items in the folder. The folders are not sorted by the total size of the items in the folder.

Select this option to sort the items alphabetically by object type. The items are sorted alphabetically by the description of their Multipurpose Internet Mail Extension (MIME) type in the File Types and Programs capplet.
Select this option to sort the items by the date the items were last modified. The most recently modified item is first.
Select this option to sort the items by any emblems that are added to the items. The items are sorted alphabetically by emblem name. Items that do not have emblems are last.
Select this option to arrange the items so that the items are closer to one another.

Select this option to reverse the order of the option by which you sort the items. For example, if you sort the items by name, select the Reversed Order option to sort the items in reverse alphabetical order.

sect3.para: Nautilus remembers how you sort the items in a particular folder. The next time that you display the folder, the items are sorted in the order you selected. In other words, when you specify how to sort the items in a folder, you customize the folder to display the items in that order.

sect3.title: To Stretch an Icon in Icon View
sect3.para: In icon view, you can change the size of the icon that represents an item that is displayed. To change the size of an item in icon view, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Right-click on the item whose size you want to change, then choose Stretch Icon. A rectangle appears around the item, with a handle at each corner.
Grab one of the handles, then drag the icon to the size that you want.
To return the icon to the original size, right-click on the icon, then choose Restore Icon's Original Size.

sect3.para: You can also stretch icons on the desktop.

sect3.title: To Sort Your Files in List View
sect3.para: To sort the contents of a folder by name, size, type, or date modified, click on the appropriate column heading above the list. An up arrow is displayed in the column heading by which the list is sorted. The following figure shows the up arrow.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of Nautilus up arrow

sect3.para: To reverse the sort order, click on the column heading again. The up arrow changes to a down arrow. The down arrow indicates that the contents of the folder are sorted in reverse order.

Nautilus remembers how you sort the items in a particular folder. The next time that you display the folder, the items are sorted in the order you selected. In other words, when you specify how to sort the items in a folder, you customize the folder to display the items in that order.

sect3.title: To Modify the Behavior of a View
sect3.para: You can modify the behavior of a view. You can do the following:

listitem.para: Specify that the view is the default view for a particular file or folder.
Specify that the view is the default view for a file type or all folders.
Specify that the view is an item in the View as drop-down list box for a particular file or folder.
Specify that the view is an item in the View as drop-down list box for all of a particular file type or for all folders.
Specify that the view is not an item in the View as drop-down list box for a particular file or folder.

sect3.para: To modify the behavior of a view perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose View as Other from the View as drop-down list box. A View as Other dialog is displayed, as shown in the following figure:

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of View as Other dialog

listitem.para: Select the view whose behavior you want to modify from the table in the dialog.
Click on the Modify button. A Modify dialog is displayed. The following table describes the options on the Modify dialog:

entry.para: Option
Description

para.guilabel: Include in the menu for item_name items

entry.para: Select this option to include the view in the View as drop-down list box for this type of item.

para.guilabel: Use as default for item_name items

entry.para: Select this option to use the view as the default for this type of item.

para.guilabel: Include in the menu just for item_name

entry.para: Select this option to include the view in the View as drop-down list box for this item only.

para.guilabel: Use as default just for item_name

entry.para: Select this option to use the view as the default for this item only.

para.guilabel: Don't include in the menu for item_name items

entry.para: Select this option to exclude the view from the View as drop-down list box for this type of item.

listitem.para: Click OK, then click Cancel to close the View as Other dialog.

note.para: You can also modify the actions that are associated with a file type in the File Types and Programs capplet. To open the File Types and Programs capplet from the Open with Other or View as Other dialogs, click on the Go There button.

sect1.title: Assigning Actions to Files
sect1.para: When you open a file, Nautilus performs the default action for that file type. The File Types and Programs capplet contains a table of file types, their associated file extensions, and their default actions. This table specifies what happens when you double-click on a file in Nautilus.
You can also use Nautilus to modify the actions that are associated with a particular file or file type. For more information, see .
You can use the File Types and Programs capplet to perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: Specify the default action for a file type. You can also change the default action for a file type in Nautilus.
Associate a file type with one or more applications. The default action might specify to open the file in an application that is associated with the file type.
Associate a file type with one or more viewers. The default action might specify to open the file in a viewer that is associated with the file type.
Associate a file extension with a MIME type. The MIME type specifies the format of the file so that Internet browsers and email applications can read the file.

sect1.para: For more information on the File Types and Programs capplet, see Configuring Document Handlers.

sect2.title: To Modify Actions
sect2.para: You can modify the actions associated with a file or file type. You can do the following:

listitem.para: Specify that the action is the default action for a particular file.
Specify that the action is the default action for a particular file type.
Specify that the action is an item in the Open With submenu for a particular file.
Specify that the action is an item in the Open With submenu for a particular file type.
Specify that the action is not an item in the Open With submenu for a particular file type.

sect2.para: To modify the actions associated with a file or file type, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: In the view pane, select the file for which you want to modify an action. If you want to modify an action associated with a file type, select a file of that type.

Choose
File Open With . Perform either of the following steps:
Choose Other Application. An Open with Other dialog is displayed.
Choose Other Viewer. A View as Other dialog is displayed.
From the table in the dialog, select the application or viewer for which you want to modify the behavior.
Click on the Modify button. A Modify dialog is displayed. The following table describes the options on the Modify dialog:

entry.para: Option
Description

para.guilabel: Include in the menu for file_type items

entry.para: Select this option to include the application or viewer in the Open With submenu for this file type.

para.guilabel: Use as default for file_type items

entry.para: Select this option to use the application or viewer as the default action for this file type.

para.guilabel: Include in the menu just for filename

entry.para: Select this option to include the application or viewer in the Open With submenu for this file, and not for other files of this type.

para.guilabel: Use as default just for filename

entry.para: Select this option to use the application or viewer as the default action for this file, and not for other files of this type.

para.guilabel: Don't include in the menu for file_type items

entry.para: Select this option to exclude the application or viewer from the Open With submenu for this file type.

listitem.para: Click OK, then click Cancel to close the dialog.

note.para: You can also modify the actions that are associated with a file type in the File Types and Programs capplet. To open the File Types and Programs capplet from the Open with Other or View as Other dialogs, click on the Go There button.

sect1.title: Customizing Nautilus
sect1.para: You can customize Nautilus to suit your requirements and preferences. This section describes how to customize Nautilus.

sect2.title: Setting Your User Level
sect2.para: Use the Preferences menu to choose a user level that is suitable for you. The user level that you choose determines what Nautilus settings you can modify in the Preferences dialog. Your user level also determines whether the Tree tab is in your navigation pane. Your Nautilus user level does not apply to the desktop in general.
describes the Nautilus user levels.

entry.para: User Level
Description

Choose Beginner as your user level if you are not familiar with the implications of changing Nautilus preferences. At Beginner user level, you can modify a minimum set of Nautilus preferences. However, you can not use the Tree tabbed pane.
Choose Intermediate as your user level if you are more familiar with the implications of changing Nautilus preferences. At Intermediate user level, you can do the following:

listitem.para: Modify more Nautilus preferences.
Use the Tree tabbed pane.

entry.para: Choose Advanced as your user level if you are familiar with the implications of making changes to all Nautilus preferences. At Advanced user level, you can do the following:

listitem.para: Modify all Nautilus preferences.
Use the Tree tabbed pane.

sect2.title: Setting Your Preferences
sect2.para:
Use the Preferences dialog to set preferences for the Nautilus windows and desktop. To display the Preferences dialog, choose
Preferences Edit Preferences .
You can set preferences in the following categories:

listitem.para: The appearance of the Nautilus windows and desktop.
The behavior of the Nautilus windows and desktop.
The behavior of items in icon views and list views.
Items that are displayed in the navigation pane.
The web search engine.
Home location and HTTP proxy details.
Speed tradeoffs to improve the performance of Nautilus.

note.para: The user level that you choose determines what Nautilus settings you can modify in the Preferences dialog.

sect3.title: To Set Appearance Preferences
sect3.para:
To set your preferences for the appearance of the Nautilus windows and desktop, choose
Preferences Edit Preferences . Choose Appearance from the Preferences dialog.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of the Appearance section of the Preferences dialog

sect3.para: lists the appearance settings that you can modify.

entry.para: Dialog Element
Description
Select this option to do the following:

listitem.para: Add a shadow to icons.
Use enhanced fonts to display icon captions.

para.guilabel: Use this font family to display file names

entry.para: Select a font in which to display file names and icon names. If the Use smoother (but slower) graphics option is selected, you can choose a font style in which to display and icon captions.

sect3.title: To Set Windows and Desktop Preferences
sect3.para:
To set your preferences for the Nautilus windows and desktop, choose
Preferences Edit Preferences . Choose Windows & Desktop from the Preferences dialog.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of the Windows and Desktop section of the Preferences dialog

sect3.para: lists the windows and desktop settings that you can modify.

entry.para: Option
Description

para.guilabel: Use Nautilus to draw the desktop

entry.para: Select this option to use Nautilus to manage your desktop. If you do not use Nautilus to manage your desktop, you can not do the following:

listitem.para: Use the File Manager menu.
Use Nautilus to change the pattern or color of the desktop.
Use the Nautilus Home launcher and Trash launcher. The Home launcher and Trash launcher are not displayed on the desktop.

para.guilabel: Open each file or folder in a separate window

entry.para: Select this option to open a new window when you open a file or folder.
Select this option to display a toolbar in new windows.

para.guilabel: Display location bar in new windows

entry.para: Select this option to display a location bar in new windows.

para.guilabel: Display status bar in new windows

entry.para: Select this option to display a statusbar in new windows.

para.guilabel: Display side bar in new windows

entry.para: Select this option to display a navigation pane in new windows.
Select this option to display a confirmation message before Trash is emptied.

sect3.title: To Set Icon and List Views Preferences
sect3.para:
To set your preferences for items in icon views and list views, choose
Preferences Edit Preferences . Choose Icon & List Views from the Preferences dialog.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of the Icon and List Views section of the Preferences dialog

sect3.para: lists the settings that you can modify for items in icon views and list views.

entry.para: Option
Description

para.guilabel: Activate items with a single click

entry.para: Select this option to perform the default action for an item when you click on the item. When this option is selected, and you point to an item, the title of the item is underlined.

para.guilabel: Activate items with a double click

entry.para: Select this option to perform the default action for an item when you double-click on the item.

para.guilabel: Execute files when they are clicked

entry.para: Select this option to run an executable file when you choose the executable file. An executable file is a text file that can execute, that is, a shell script.

para.guilabel: Display files when they are clicked

entry.para: Select this option to display the contents of an executable file when you choose the executable file.
Select this option to display a dialog when you choose an executable file. The dialog asks whether you want to execute the file or display the file.
Select this option to display hidden files in the view pane. The first character in a hidden file name is a period (.).
Select this option to display backup files in the view pane. The last character in a backup file name is a tilde (~).

para.guilabel: Show special flags in Properties window

entry.para: Select this option to show the following special flags in the Permissions tab on the Properties dialog:

sect3.title: To Set Navigation Pane Preferences
sect3.para:
To set your preferences for the navigation pane, choose
Preferences Edit Preferences . Choose Sidebar Panels from the Preferences dialog.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of the Sidebar Panels section of the Preferences dialog

sect3.para: lists the navigation pane settings that you can modify.

entry.para: Option
Description
Select this option to display the Help tab in the navigation pane.
Select this option to display the History tab in the navigation pane.
Select this option to display the Notes tab in the navigation pane.
Select this option to display the Tree tab in the navigation pane.

para.guilabel: Show only folders (no files) in the tree

entry.para: Select this option to display only folders in the Tree tabbed pane.

sect3.title: To Set Search Preferences
sect3.para:
To set your search engine preferences, choose
Preferences Edit Preferences . Choose Search from the Preferences dialog.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of the Search section of the Preferences dialog

sect3.para: lists the search engine settings that you can modify.

entry.para: Dialog Element
Description
Enter the URL of the search engine to access when you choose to perform a web search in Nautilus.

sect3.title: To Set Navigation Preferences
sect3.para:
To set navigation preferences, choose
Preferences Edit Preferences . Choose Navigation from the Preferences dialog.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of the Navigation section of the Preferences dialog

sect3.para: lists the navigation settings that you can modify.

entry.para: Dialog Element
Description
Enter the location that you want to use as your home page. Enter your home location as follows:

listitem.para: To specify a web page as your home location, enter the URL in the Home Location field.
To specify a file or folder as your home location, enter the path in the Home Location field.

entry.para: Select this option to use a proxy server for the HTTP service.
Enter the DNS name or the IP address of the proxy server to use when you request a HTTP service.
Enter the port number of the HTTP service on the proxy server.

para.guilabel: Don't include the built-in bookmarks in the Bookmarks menu

entry.para: Select this option to exclude the default bookmarks that are supplied with Nautilus from the Bookmarks menu.

sect3.title: To Set Speed Tradeoffs Preferences
sect3.para: Some Nautilus features can affect the speed with which Nautilus responds to your requests. You can modify the behavior of some of these features to improve the speed of Nautilus. In this way, you can exchange, or trade off, a Nautilus feature for better performance. For each of the speed tradeoff preferences, you can select one of the options described in the following table:

entry.para: Option
Description
Performs the action for both local files and files on other file systems.
Performs the action for local files only.
Never performs the action.

sect3.para:
To set your speed tradeoff preferences,
Preferences Edit Preferences . Choose Speed Tradeoffs from the Preferences dialog.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of the Speed Tradeoffs section of the Preferences dialog

sect3.para: lists the search speed tradeoff settings that you can modify.

entry.para: Dialog Element
Description
Select an option to specify when to preview the content of text files in the icon that represents the file.

para.guilabel: Show Count of Items in Folders

entry.para: Select an option to specify when to show the number of items in folders.
Select an option to specify when to show thumbnails of image files. Nautilus stores the thumbnail files for each folder in a .thumbnails directory that is one level below the folder.
Select an option to specify when to preview sound files.
Select an option to specify when to make folder appearance details public.

sect2.title: Changing Themes and Backgrounds
sect2.para: Nautilus includes themes and backgrounds that you can use to change the look-and-feel of the Nautilus windows and desktop.

sect3.title: To Change Your Nautilus Theme
sect3.para: To change your Nautilus theme perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
Choose
Edit Nautilus Themes . The Nautilus Theme Selector dialog is displayed.
Choose a theme from the Nautilus Theme list.
Click Done to close the dialog.

sect3.title: To Add a Nautilus Theme
sect3.para: To add a theme to Nautilus perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
Choose
Edit Nautilus Themes .
Click on the Add New Theme button on the Nautilus Theme Selector dialog. A dialog is displayed. Use the dialog to find the new theme.
Click OK to add the new theme to the Nautilus Theme Selector dialog.

sect3.para: Nautilus themes are stored as directories in the /opt/gnome-1.4/share/pixmaps/nautilus/ directory.

sect3.title: To Change Your Backgrounds
sect3.para: You can change the background of the following screen components:

listitem.para: Nautilus desktop
Navigation pane
View pane
Panels, except for the Menu Panel

sect3.para: To change the background of a screen component perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
Choose
Edit Backgrounds and Emblems . The Backgrounds and Emblems dialog is displayed.
To display a list of patterns that you can use on the background, click on the Patterns button. To display a list of the colors that you can use on the background, click on the Colors button.
To change the background to a pattern, drag the pattern to the screen component. To change the background to a color, drag the color to the screen component.
Click Done to close the dialog.

sect3.para: When you change the background of the navigation pane or the view pane of a particular folder, Nautilus remembers the background that you chose for the folder. The next time that you display the folder, the background that you selected is displayed. In other words, when you change the background of a folder, you customize the folder to display the background.

sect3.title: To Add a Pattern
sect3.para:
To add a pattern to the patterns that you can use on your screen components, choose
Edit Backgrounds and Emblems . Click on the Patterns button, then click on the Add New Pattern button. A dialog is displayed. Use the dialog to find the new pattern. Click OK to add the new pattern to the Backgrounds and Emblems dialog.

sect3.title: To Add a Color
sect3.para:
To add a color to the colors that you can use on your screen components, choose
Edit Backgrounds and Emblems . Click on the Colors button, then click on the Add New Color button. A color selector dialog is displayed. Use the color wheel or the sliders to choose the color. Click OK to add the new color to the Backgrounds and Emblems dialog.

sect2.title: To Show and Hide Window Components
sect2.para: You can show and hide Nautilus window components as follows:

listitem.para:
To hide the navigation pane, choose
View Hide Sidebar . To display the navigation pane again, choose
View Show Sidebar .

To hide the toolbar, choose
View Hide Toolbar . To display the toolbar again, choose
View Show Toolbar .

To hide the location bar, choose
View Hide Location Bar . To display the location bar again, choose
View Show Location Bar .

To hide the statusbar, choose
View Hide Status Bar . To display the navigation pane statusbar again, choose
View Show Status Bar .

To remove a tab from the navigation pane, right-click in the navigation pane. Choose the tab that you want to remove from the menu. To add the tab to the navigation pane again, choose the tab from the menu again.
